ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to a live virtual lecture, I also took part in weekly discussion sections.
For the most part I just watched the recordings, but I did occasionally tune in to the live lectures.
Virtual lecture + virtual office hours/section
sections
Plus weekly discussion sections
In addition to live virtual lectures (which were recorded as well), there were optional virtual live discussion sections.
I attended every live virtual lecture and virtual discussion session.
Live virtual lecture
Live section, peer tutor hours, office hours
The class offered live lectures, as well as an option to watch these lectures later on Canvas.
Live virtual lecture with weekly section
recorded lecture, live virtual discussion section
Live virtual discussion sections
Virtual lectures and review sessions. Lectures were also recorded for flexibility and review.
We also had virtual TA sections over Zoom.
Recorded and live virtual lectures
We also had section and review sessions with office hours and such.
Recorded lectures plus going over lecture notes and summaries and using the book for help.
Weekly section
The live virtual lectures were also all recorded.
recorded lecture
N/A
Optional virtual sections.
I attended section and office hours for live learning sessions
We also had virtual discussion sections.
Live virtual lectures with optional sections.
recorded lectures, virtual discussion sections
In addition to the live virtual action, I also attended section, which was helpful
Synchornous section
Live lecture
Recorded lecture as well
Live virtual lecture that was recorded to be available on Canvas.
Also posted the live lectures as a recording. Included review sessions for exams, office hours, and discussion sections with a teaching fellow.
There were also discussion sections.
Most of the time I watched the lecture live, but sometimes utilized the recorded lectures.
Live virtual section
N/A
self revision of past papers problem sets and textbook questions
lectures were also recorded
We also had live virtual discussion sections.
N/A
Live virtual lecture plus a live virtual discussion-based section
none... textbooks??
Lectures were live, and recordings were made available. My discussion section was not recorded but I don't know if others were.
Lectures were live on Zoom, although also accessible via Canvas recordings. The same is true of class discussion sections.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A basic overview of macroeconomics and macroeconomic forces.

The course definitely reaffirmed my disdain for economics as an academic discipline. It really is just the equivalent of astrology. The sheer number of comically simple graphs to post-hoc explain phenomena with literally thousands of explanatory factors makes me cringe so hard.
I learned basic macroeconomics in the short-run and long-run, including the Solow model, the business cycle, etc. We also were exposed to some recent economics research papers, which was great.

Although my note-taking skills did not greatly improve from this course, as most of the covered content was provided in the format of slides, my confidence and ability to ask questions did improve. As a quiet individual, I found the discussion sections a great place to get my questions answered, while not facing the pressure of 70 other students in the (virtual) room. I also learned to utilize the resources provided to you, especially in the forms of peer tutors, as they have grown to become a weekly part of my schedule.
Foundation of macroeconomics, insight to current macro data
Good foundation of macro economics. Bonds, financial system, GDP, trade, labor market.
I developed a basic understanding of macroeconomics, and some of the mathematical tools to analyze macroeconomic trends.

I learned how to calculate real GDP, unemployment/employment rates, stock value, and inflation, among other things. I also learned about the different causes of economic growth, the role of various important institutions like the Fed, how international trade works and its benefits and drawbacks, and the applications of economics to COVID and climate change.
I learned a lot about the state of affairs of the world in light of the pandemic, and larger macroeconomic trends.

This class is a wonderful introduction to macroeconomics and covers topics such as taxation, GDP, labor markets, monetary policy, growth models, etc. I definitely felt that it gave me a great insight into this field. I especially appreciated how the professors made the material relevant by relating it to current events such as COVID and climate change.
I learned the basics of macroeconomics including some basic finance knowledge. This was a good course to gain more awareness about global economic issues.

I think the class helped me think more critically and analytically when I view economic data/material in the news. It was empowering to learn essential concepts of macroeconomics, especially since I'm considering a career in public service. I feel well-prepared to pursue further economics at Yale and feel that I am equipped with a pretty-detailed understanding of why and how concepts like GDP, interest rates, institutions, etc. interact with each other and shape the economy.
Knowledge of GDP, Taxes, etc.
Introduction to basic macro topics.
I learned a lot about the economy and I liked the connections we made with COVID-19.
I learnt the importance of going to section.
General Macro insights, how monetary policy works, Fed, general macroeconomic policy.
learned a lot about the basics of econ and financial institutions.
Basic macroeconomic principles and simple analytical skills
I developed my understanding of broader economic concepts
you learn about basic economic theories and the process economists follow to answer questions about the world
Banks, fin institutions, etc.
This class gave a nice overview of macro principles in a way that connected lessons to events in the world.

I learned a great deal about macroeconomics, touching a great deal on subjects like labor,  employment, International trade, and the Financial Crisis of 2008.  I essentially learned all of the basics of macroeconomics.  It's actually quite incredible how much you can understand about economics and economic discourse after just taking this intro course.
Economics
Aggregate supply/demand, Solow model, AS/AD model, fiscal and monetary policy, GDP, quantity theory of money, climate change, basic finance concepts.
Learned about some basic models used in Macroeconomics
Macro econ. All the curriculum
Fiscal and monetary policies
An introduction to macro
I learned more about the field of macroeconomics and developed important skills in analyzing economic information.
Econ concepts
basic economic models, applications to covid and to climate change
Macroeconomic principles.
I learned how to apply theories and concepts from macroeconomics to the greater context of the US economy as well as the impact due to covid.
The importance of going to office hours to seek help was really highlighted for me during this class.
I took away a full course of macroeconomics and I feel confident in my ability to relay that information.
how the world evolves around us and what causes institutions to do what they do
I learned more about what goes on economically at the macro level.
I developed a strong understanding of fundamental macroeconomic concepts and trends.

I developed a strong macroeconomic foundation for topics like trade, monetary/fiscal policy, aggregate supply/demand, labor, debt, and more. I now have a solid insight into how policy changes affect the economy.
Learned about production and global economic growth

I learned a lot more about global economics and how certain countries are richer than others. I also learned a lot more about the nuances of the United States economy which helped contextualize a lot of what we experienced in 2020
I gained a basic understanding of macro-economics and its applications.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths of this course were relating the topics to real world examples and current events, as well as the quizzes to let us try and retain the knowledge.

"TikTok for Cats" and "Crazy Donut" are just two reaosns why Aleh is the goat. Well, really, Hawkins and Tsyvinski are the goats. Both are great at teaching concepts clearly and have an uncanny humor. Makes for fun lectures.
Just let Hawkins teach it

This course had many strengths. Lectures were generally interesting and enjoyable. The weekly sections were especially helpful, as the chance to work through problems was always great, and Hawkins is incredible at teaching. I don't have any specific feedback in terms of how it could be improved, except that it might be nice to provide more quantitative proofs and explanations for the things we learned; as someone who learns better when theories are backed by numerical explanations, I felt that it might have been helpful if a bit more (maybe optional) math could have been used.
This course was well-organized, and I believe the problem sets and exams were really fair to what we learned in class. I don't have any weaknesses to list about it.

The largest strength of this course is its organization and sheer amount of resources dedicated towards the class. This, when utilized properly, helps with all facets of the course, from difficult problem set questions to test review to clarifying new concepts.

The professors did an excellent job with the lectures. Information was easily conveyed in the virtual format, and Professor Hawkins was an excellent "moderator" who helped things go smooth and answer questions. 

The sections felt like a little bit of a waste of time, not much value add. I think the content of the section could be improved.
Strengths: extremely organized and well maintained canvas site; Kortum's lecture slides were difficult to follow and there was little cohesion between the different professor's lectures
Overall the class was very organized and fair

Weaknesses: professor Kortum. Before fall 2020 only Aleh taught the class and everyone loved it, but the duet of Aleh and professor Kortum definitely did not work out this semester. Professor Kortum was just reading the slides and did not really explain the material properly. So I ended up understanding topics taught by Kortum way worse than the ones taught by Aleh. It was also hard to switch between professors, as their teaching techniques are different. The biggest issue was that the material taught in lecture was very surface, while exams and psets asked for way deeper knowledge. The grading of psets was vert weird too for the same reason. Giving one explanation for the question was not enough and I ended up losing so many points for not giving 3-4 different perspectives. Strength: I guess this class gives a good end to the econ intro sequence.
Great lecturers and the course is very well-run. It could be improved by offering a bit more help on problem sets (they were pretty hard and no instructor gave straightforward help).

One strength of this course is that there are plenty of opportunities to ask questions about the material throughout the semester, and especially in the weeks leading up to an exam (there are plenty of review sessions). I think the course was also very well organized in terms of how lectures were grouped together in themes and the order in which these themes were presented (themes included but were not limited to GDP, trade, money, financial institutions, and financial crises). I also appreciate that weekly quizzes allow for unlimited attempts so you are able to get some practice before having to submit the p-set for the week.

Areas for improvement are defining terms more clearly during the lecture, taking more time to explain the more complex equations and what each term of the equation means, and generally making lecture slides easier to understand/more useful for review.
The problem sets were not really reflective of what you would see on the midterms or finals, but they were still engaging.
It was very well organised and help was always available.

Strengths: TA office hours were incredibly helpful and constructive. All of the TAs are helpful and great at explaining concepts in a more direct setting beyond lecture. 
Weaknesses: some of the lectures were disorganized in that it was challenging to holistically grasp concepts.

The strength I appreciated most was how much help was available to us at all times. The profs, Dr. Hawkins, TAs, and peer tutors were always willing to help and explain concepts. I was so thankful for how many review sessions and office hours were offered throughout the semester. That was amazing, and I really appreciated it. Looking to the future, I think a potential weakness is that it might be nice to see more example problems in the lecture (but the profs and Dr. Hawkins did an excellent job incorporating this feedback and responding to it the second half of the semester).
Pretty easy and straightforward class. Good professors
The lectures were better than any other intro Econ class. I enjoyed listening to them. The weekly quizzes were also useful.

Strength: I appreciate that it was recorded and the files, summaries, and such could be found online.

Weakness: Exams and such can be exhausting to prepare for, given the circumstances.
The course lessons were much easier than the problem sets and exams, there was not enough opportunity to practice questions.

Strength; interesting topics sometimes ,quizzes arent too bad 
Weaknesses: a bit weird when theres two professors, find a study group for psets
the course was done well
Classes felt a little long
Weaknesses: lectures need to be less confusing, paced slower

weaknesses: Lecture slides could be clearer especially when it comes to review; felt a bit lost when had to review for midterms and exams. Feedback on psets were not helpful for review as the answer key was often very vague

Strengths:  
-->It is a very all-encompassing class, you learn a lot about Econ
-->It doesn't have too much math
-->The professors are great
-->The class runs very well, even during the pandemic
Weaknesses
-->The Class can be a bit fast, but honestly it's not if you keep up
-->Very concepts based (which was good for me as a Political science student, but might be bad for math-y people)
-->Doesn't accept late work
Hard to learn over zoom
Strengths were Professor Hawkins and Professor Tsyvinski in particular. The weekly quizzes were effective in ensuring that everyone was caught up with the material.

Strengths: it was very well-organized and the assignments for every week were always very clear

Weakness: often felt quite passive, especially in lecture

Strength: good lecturers, interesting material
Weaknesses: at times can be rambley or go on tangent, but not too long tangents.
I feel like Kortum's lectures could use more structure. Aleh's structure is a definitely strength, and Hawkins always makes section engaging and informative
Good course
Very entertaining professors, and engaging lectures
I did not think the live lectures helped, actually thought it detracted from the class. at a certain point, ended up just watching recorded lectures and felt that went a lot better.
Only strengths
Accessibility of office hours by TAs/peer tutors was very good, as were all the resources provided by Dr. Hawkins. He helped make sure the course ran very smoothly.

This course is very interesting and the professors are very down to earth and willing to explain anything you don't completely understand in a way that you will completely understand. Professor Hawkins' lecture summaries are INCREDIBLE.

Strengths are that the discussion sections and peer tutors were very helpful with going further in depth with examples. A weakness was that sometimes the material would be covered very quickly and it was tough to instantly get all the concepts.

Professor Tsyvinski definitely kept the class fun and informative. Sometimes went a bit fast but I really appreciated the side jokes he would have with Professor Hawkins. Professor Kortum was more to-the-book, but still informative.
Virtually I thought it was run well. I only wish that there was more time for in-class discussion, but it is what it is.
strengths are that it covers all of the basics of macroeconomics. weaknesses are that it goes so fast and through so much material you don't have time to truly grasp any concept

The teachers are very good. One suggestion for the weekly quizzes: if they could be posted on gradescope instead, so that if someone gets only one or two questions wrong they don't have to redo the whole quiz but can instead redo only those two questions. Also, it would be great to include more material about other countries other than the US.
This course moves very quickly, and, due to the limitations of Zoom, does not offer many opportunities to access help outside of class.

The biggest strength of this course is its instructors: Dr. Hawkins, Dr. Tsyvinski, and Dr. Kortum. Dr. Tsyvinksi and Dr. Kortum are incredible teachers; they know what they're talking about and do their best to make the material as engaging and useful as possible. Dr. Hawkins is the professor behind the scenes making sure everything runs smoothly, and he does that exceptionally well. Dr. Hawkins tries the best he can to make sure that the course is well-organized and that no student gets left behind. All three of them are extremely knowledgeable about macroeconomics and pick what they believe are going to be both fascinating and practical topics to learn. I can't really think of any weaknesses of this course; I loved it very much!

Strengths: good textbook, good practice questions

weaknesses: the lectures can be made more productive and the problem sets were sometimes a little vague in terms of their instruction

The professors are amazing and Dr. Hawkins was always on top of everything logistical and all the professors were really great at answering questions. However, I wish we could have studied inequality more
The information is taught in an accessible, but not overbearing way. Overall, I cannot think of a way to improve it.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed learning about how the macroeconomic concepts could be applied to the current COVID-19 pandemic. It made me feel closer to the material. The professors were very engaging and enthusiastic about the course, which made it easier to learn. Dr. Hawkins was very supportive and understanding of each student's needs and I really appreciated his willingness to help and advise me when I needed it. This is all especially relevant as each student is dealing with his or her own situation at home/on campus, and I think that the practices employed by the course directors were excellent. The peer tutor office hours were also very helpful in the hours before the problem set deadlines.
The online quizzes definitely helped my learning, and it was nice that the professors allocated some time for a break in between lecture.

Weekly psets were pretty obnoxious.

Hawkins definitely had to see a weekly chiropractor the way he carried this course on his back. I know he already probably spends four hours a day cleaning up the pedagogical messes that the profs leave for him, but the profs should also have to filter the slides through Hawkins to make them coherent before using them.
Virtual tools were used well.

I think the discussion sections, although virtual, were engaging and greatly helpful, mostly due to a small size and use of breakout rooms. The lectures, on the other hand, were typically rushed, as the course had a lot of content to cover in the allotted time. While there were some opportunities for questions, I do not think there was enough engagement, partially due to remote learning, so many questions went unasked, and, therefore, unanswered.
I felt the exam method was well done and conducive to learning while still being examined
I think the combination of low-stake quizes and graded prolbem sets worked out well. And it was good that there was an option to rewatch lectures later on.

Section was actually pretty great; well adapted for the virtual format. The instructors were also really engaging, especially Prof. Tsyvinski, and there was a good amount of interaction with students' questions.
They did a really great job of providing virtual support through office hours and piazza.
I think having each lecture recorded was very helpful.

I really appreciated filming the lectures. I loved watching the lectures live, but sometimes things came up and I had to watch the recording instead. I thought that was thoughtful and considerate of the instructors. I also was thankful that the professors adopted an open-note exam policy for the semester. I think continuing the in-lecture breaks that we started in the second half of the semester would be awesome. It helped me focus more.
Recorded lectures were nice if you missed the live one.
The weekly quizzes helped a lot. I'd advise to take them seriously. The textbook was also surprisingly useful.
I think the summaries and lecture slides online with recording was super helpful. I think there could be an improvement in making important math-y content concise.
Recorded lessons succeeded but having two instructors was not helpful.
I liked the unlimited quiz attempts
Virtual engagement was good

I appreciated that the course director and professors adapted examinations to the virtual format and allowed for open book/notes examinations. The nature of the questions still required a deep understanding of the material.

strengths: professors were very receptive to feedback and changed exam times/meeting lengths to accommodate students

weaknesses: didnt have to have as many psets considering the times and a few of the quizzes felt more like busy work than learning material

I liked how all of the lectures were recorded as well as some of the discussion sections.  I also liked how the book was a pdf.  I wish there was some more consistency in recording discussion sections, however.
Polling the class succeeded, while certain subject material failed to engage. Could be improved by requiring videos to be on.
Virtual lectures were good. Having the recorded lectures in the media library also helped. Breaking up the larger lecture into smaller virtual discussion sections worked well, too.
maybe more polls during class to increase engagement
Section was good. And I really appreciated that the course was always open to feedback
More feedback input from students
I appreciated that both live and recorded lectures were offered.
I think this course followed pretty standard COVID-19 pandemic procedures and succeeded at them.
I think the discussions worked very well as they were very collaborative due to the small size. The lectures also worked quite well this semester despite the difficulties due to COVID.
Recorded lectures and monitoring the chat during lecture to answer questions were both successful practices for the virtual class.
I really appreciated sections and the review sessions offered. The office hours were very flexible too.
I appreciated the patience the instructors showed with students. Especially in the test-taking environment.
recording the lectures were good, and all review sessions were at the best times for everyone and were also recorded

I appreciated that lecture recordings were made available after each class, and the multitude of review sessions were very helpful to accommodate students with different schedules. However, this class could benefit from an increased frequency of office hours before assignments are due as well as better feedback on past assignments after they have been graded.

I thought this course adapted exceptionally well to a remote setting. Having two engaging professors switch out every few lectures (Prof. Tsyvinski and Prof. Kortum) kept the course fresh and exciting despite it being on Zoom. Piazza was a really great way for me to ask any questions I had about the material; huge thank you to Prof. Hawkins for responding so quickly and thoroughly to every Piazza post! Assignments on Canvas and p-sets on Gradescope were well adapted to remote settings, and exams were especially well-adapted because they were open-book on Canvas but still challenging enough to warrant an average that wasn't exceedingly high or low. Office and peer tutoring hours were well organized and accessible to many time zones. One thing I believe could be improved is working through examples in lecture, especially writing math out on the screen. The course made up for it with examples in section, but I think there were definitely certain scenarios during lecture that could've warranted a pause to work through an example on the screen.

successful = recorded lecture plus section notes
unsuccessful = test taking format

The professors adapted very well to virtual learning, I really liked how there were plenty of opportunities to attend virtual office hours and still get individual instruction despite it being virtual
Having recorded class sections was very helfpul, since it made reviewing difficult material very easy. It would be great if that would continue to be accessible to students post-COVID.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course. Even if you took some iteration of macroeconomics in high school, this class provides a number tools essential to the analysis of large-scale trends and real-world events which you can benefit from in a tangible way. Its also very enjoyable, and the problem sets, while not unchallenging, are both manageable and helpful for practicing the material.
Yes, if they want to learn about macroeconomics!

Yes, if they haven't taken AP macro; no if they have. The most salient additions to this class apart from AP Macro are the Solow Model and Financial markets--albeit these are two great topics. Having said that, I think AP macro sufficiently covers these topics as well as more, so you'd be wasting your time by taking this class. If you haven't taken AP macro though, this class is an awesome introduction to macro. The models are covered quite well and the concepts learned are essential building blocks for future courses.

Yes, this class was pretty great (significantly better than the intro micro lecture course). Topics covered were interesting and both Kortum and Tsyvinski often linked the material studied to recent economic trends and things in the news, etc. In terms of intellectual challenge, this course was really very doable overall. There was extremely little math, even compared to intro micro. Also, Hawkins is really incredible as a course director -- he teaches so well, his sense of humor is great, etc. Definitely take the course with Tsyvinski and Hawkins if you can.
Yes. I took it for the economics major, but I would also recommend it to students who are not economics majors. It teaches you a lot about the real world and practical economics knowledge.

Yes, in fact, I would recommend this course to others, and I already have. The course is incredibly well-organized, which, if the student is willing to put in the effort, allows for greater success. There are plenty of practice tests and other resources, making preparation for the exams straightforward. In addition, there are various helpful resources provided that make the class an enjoyable and fruitful experience, such as TFs, Peer Tutors, Office Hours, and Discussion Section.
Yes, good knowledge foundation to have

People who want to have good foundation of economics probably should take this class, because there are also no other options. But take it only if Aleh is the only professor who is teaching the class.

Yes, it was a pretty good background to macroeconomics. Prof. Tsyvinski is an engaging (and funny) lecturer and the class is well-run. Prof. Hawkins definitely is a great section leader, and you should try to get him if possible.

I would recommend this course because it is important to understand the causes of economic growth, policies that help with growth, the history behind the current global economic order, and economics' application to issues like COVID and climate change. Hearing concepts for the first time can definitely be confusing, but practice via quizzes and discussion sections definitely helped.
Yes, if you are interested in learning about economic trends.
Absolutely! Although most people probably just take it for the requirements, it is well taught and the content is interesting. It's also very fair and not stressful while still being very useful.

Yes! It gives you a thorough, comprehensive introduction to macroeconomics. The profs are super nice, Prof Hawkins does an excellent job organizing the class, and the TAs are all great. You always feel supported by the instructors, and they are always there for you to ask for help.
Yes, it is a great introductory econ course.

Its an Econ pre-req so I assume most are taking it for the major requirements. Other than that, a somewhat interesting course for non-majors. Would recommend if you're interested in basic Econ concepts.
I took it for Global Affairs and I recommend it for that! If it's required, take it. If not, it depends on your interest in economics.
No. Unless it is being taught by one Professor alone.
yes
Yes
I would only if they have an appreciation for or interest in economics

I recommend this course to any student who wants to understand the basic functions of the economy. For non-econ students, I think this course is valuable to understanding how policymakers utilize macro economics to push certain economic policies.
If you have to take an econ course for your major, I would recommend taking macro! If not and youre taking it for fun, Im not so sure as you would need to make sure youre dedicated to studying.

I certainly would recommend this class to other students.  Firstly, the professors are great and very informative.  Secondly, and most importantly, the content is very good.  This course is a holy grail for political science students to get a bit of a background understanding for economics and some of the most important aspects of it which affect political discourse (such as labor and trade).  Even students who find that math is not their strong suit will find this class to be both informative and positively challenging.  Anybody who wants to learn about how the economy overall works will learn a great deal from this class.
Yes, learned a lot of useful terminology.
Yes. The basics of macroeconomics are relevant to anyone in any field. This class serves as a great overview of the fundamental concepts.
If you need it for your major, then obviously yes, but you will not learn anything ground-breaking.
Yes! Macro > micro, hot take.
Yes. Macro > Micro anyday. Aleh and Hawkins are gods among us. Super interesting to learn about their own research in the curriculum
Yes if they are an economic major
Sure, its interesting and engaging
Yes it was an amazing course with amazing instructors and structure

I would definitely recommend this course. Professors Tsyvinski and Kortum both tried their hardest to make the class engaging while all on Zoom, and Hawkins made sure to make all slides and course materials available and accessible.
Yes. Very interesting and if Intro Micro makes you question whether or not you want to be an Econ major, this class will remind you of why you were even considering Econ in the first place.
I would recommend it to anyone because it is always helpful to have some general knowledge in the field of economics.
Yes, especially if they are interested in economics.
Yes, it's a great course and the Professors know so much. I really liked it when they showed us their research.

I would but only if they are an Econ major or have a lot of time/passion to dedicate to the course. I am not an Econ major and was quite interested coming in, but the course is so fast paced that I found myself extremely stressed out by it
Yes, it provides useful insights into important topics I feel everyone should know.
I would not recommend this class in a lecture format.

Yes I would! This course is exceptionally well-taught, even in a remote setting. The professors are engaging, really care about their students, and adapt the material to the current economy and government policies (like the coronavirus and the CARES act or climate change), as well as to topics students seem most interested in. I think macroeconomics is an extremely interesting topic, and anyone even remotely interested in government policies and money should definitely try it out!
Yes, I think it covers most of your bases in terms of general economic topics, and the way that economic models are made are quite interesting and helpful to understand
Yes!

If you are curious about macro-economics (or if you have to take this course as a pre-requisite), you are in good hands! The course is well organized and there are almost too many resources available to help you master the material. The professors also do a good job of relating course content to its real-world applications, which makes the lectures very interesting.
